body:
Unfortunately using gpu still fails the same way:
tmp = mx.model.FeedForward.load(model_sty, load_epoch, ctx = mx.gpu())
  File "/mxnet/mx_env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/mxnet-0.5.0-py3.4.egg/mxnet/model.py", line 344, in load_checkpoint
    symbol = sym.load('%s-symbol.json' % prefix)
  File "/mxnet/mx_env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/mxnet-0.5.0-py3.4.egg/mxnet/symbol.py", line 769, in load
    check_call(_LIB.MXSymbolCreateFromFile(c_str(fname), ctypes.byref(handle)))
  File "/mxnet/mx_env/lib/python3.4/site-packages/mxnet-0.5.0-py3.4.egg/mxnet/base.py", line 76, in check_call
    raise MXNetError(py_str(_LIB.MXGetLastError()))

I think issue is that model in kaggle-ndsb2 has some image processing which it cannot able to load. Since my GPU is 860M, I like to run it in small chunks to prevent overheating so I prefer saving/loading models. possinbly the original ticket has also has some complex model that is failing. Since main code is C it is difficult to to debug from python side exactly what part it is failing.
i think we should use `ADD_CFLAGS = -DMSHADOW_USE_SSE=0` (only one C) while not `ADD_CCFLAGS`

I have compiled mxnet on Tk1.

Besides the `ADD_CFLAGS`, you also need to remove `-msse2` in https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc-core/blob/master/Makefile#L14
@thirdwing nice! how is the performance of tk1 comparing to other common cards, such as k40 or gtx 750 ti?
It is a GPU for mobile devices (like Dji's quadrone), so not powerful.
You have USE_CUDA_PATH = NONE in your config.mk. Change it to USE_CUDA_PATH = /share/sw/modules/Core/cuda/7.5/

yeah, i know that. so my question is that how is it comparing to some common
nvidia gpu? for example, i guess tx1 is roughly equal to 15% k40? i just
want to get a sense how many frames we may get if run prediction on tx1.

another question is, is there anyone has put tk1 on dji successfully?

I can run some benchmarks later.

Tk1 is part of the official SDK https://developer.dji.com/manifold/
You can change the launch script to set different batch_size for each process.
many thanks for the link, i didn't know that before. have you heard any news that when dji will put tx1 onboard? tx1 is much more interesting since it's almost 4x faster than tk1 if using FP16.

@pluskid In the TensorFlow model (disjoint graph support) it is still up to the user to bucket their data and pad each segment to the closest bucket. So one minibatch would contain all segments of length 11-25, padded to be exactly 25. In most applications I can think of, this is fine.

> The whole network has to have the same recurrence sequence pattern (e.g. forward sweeping through the input sequence, backward sweeping, etc.). 

Most architectures which get state-of-the-art results on various NLP tasks (and not just NLP -- speech recognition, video processing, etc) do not have such a simple pattern. We could design an API which works for certain architectures _now_ (like seq2seq+attention), but who knows what type of architectures will become popular in the near future. The only truly general mechanism is to let the user specify whatever graph they want -- which MxNet already lets you do, but only for a single connected graph.

For example, consider the _recursive_ neural network architecture where the network is a binary tree. The leaf nodes are the data, and the intermediate nodes all share the same parameters (it could be a fully connected layer or an LSTM-like layer).

```
     N
  /    \
  N     N
 / \  /  \
a   b c  d
```

It would be extremely difficult to design an API that allows for variable length sequences here. But the bucketing method would work naturally.

There are other advantages to the bucketing method (e.g., supporting multiple sub graphs that share parameters), namely, they easily allow for multi-task/multi-modal training. For example, you could train a translation model and a language model jointly and tie certain parameters together. In this case, you would specify two disjoint graphs, and randomly alternate whether the minibatch corresponds to the translation model or the language model. The embedding layer (and possibly other layers) would be tied together.
`executor.backward(out_grads=mx.nd.ones((3, 6)))` -> `executor.backward(out_grads=[mx.nd.ones((3, 6))])`
I tried and it gave the same error.

```

x = mx.nd.empty((3, 6))
dx = mx.nd.empty((3, 6))
x_value = np.random.rand(3, 6).astype('float32')
print x_value
mx.nd.array(x_value).copyto(x)

xV = mx.symbol.Variable('x')
out = xV + 1

executor = out.bind(ctx=mx.cpu(), args={'x': x}, args_grad={'x': dx})
executor.forward()
outputs = executor.outputs
print outputs[0].asnumpy()  # as expected
executor.backward(out_grads=[mx.nd.ones((3, 6))])  # error
```

This works for me.
You didn't bind gradients so the executor was not built with backward enabled.
Thanks!

Which blas library are you using.
Could you post your config.mk

I download the thirdparty library from BaiduYun: http://pan.baidu.com/s/1kTrQmn9,it includes OpenBlas.

the config.mk:
#---------------------

# choice of compiler

#--------------------

export CC = gcc
export CXX = g++
export NVCC = nvcc

# whether compile with debug

DEBUG = 0

# the additional link flags you want to add

ADD_LDFLAGS =

# the additional compile flags you want to add

ADD_CFLAGS =

#---------------------------------------------

# matrix computation libraries for CPU/GPU

#---------------------------------------------

# whether use CUDA during compile

USE_CUDA = 0

# add the path to CUDA library to link and compile flag

# if you have already add them to environment variable, leave it as NONE

# USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda

USE_CUDA_PATH = NONE

# whether use CuDNN R3 library

USE_CUDNN = 0

# whether use cuda runtime compiling for writing kernels in native language (i.e. Python)

USE_NVRTC = 0

# whether use opencv during compilation

# you can disable it, however, you will not able to use

# imbin iterator

USE_OPENCV = 1

# use openmp for parallelization

USE_OPENMP = 1

# choose the version of blas you want to use

# can be: mkl, blas, atlas, openblas

# in default use atlas for linux while apple for osx

UNAME_S := $(shell uname -s)
ifeq ($(UNAME_S), Darwin)
USE_BLAS = apple
else
USE_BLAS = atlas
endif

# add path to intel library, you may need it for MKL, if you did not add the path

# to environment variable

USE_INTEL_PATH = NONE

# If use MKL, choose static link automatically to allow python wrapper

ifeq ($(USE_BLAS), mkl)
USE_STATIC_MKL = 1
else
USE_STATIC_MKL = NONE
endif

#----------------------------

# distributed computing

#----------------------------

# whether or not to enable multi-machine supporting

USE_DIST_KVSTORE = 0

# whether or not allow to read and write HDFS directly. If yes, then hadoop is

# required

USE_HDFS = 0

# path to libjvm.so. required if USE_HDFS=1

LIBJVM=$(JAVA_HOME)/jre/lib/amd64/server

# whether or not allow to read and write AWS S3 directly. If yes, then

# libcurl4-openssl-dev is required, it can be installed on Ubuntu by

# sudo apt-get install -y libcurl4-openssl-dev

USE_S3 = 0

#----------------------------

# additional operators

#----------------------------

# path to folders containing projects specific operators that you don't want to put in src/operators

EXTRA_OPERATORS =

#----------------------------

# plugins

#----------------------------

# whether to use torch integration. This requires installing torch.

# TORCH_PATH = $(HOME)/torch

# MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/torch/torch.mk

# whether to use sframe integration. This requires build sframe

# git@github.com:dato-code/SFrame.git

# SFRAME_PATH = $(HOME)/SFrame

# MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/sframe/plugin.mk

Are you building with visual studio or mingw?

@gary30404 CUDA 6.5

Thank you all. 
I have succeeded by doing these:
ADD_CFLAGS = -DMSHADOW_USE_SSE=0
remove msse3 and msse2

Adding a function to explicit perform partial shape inference seems unnecessary. 
Partial shape inference in tensorflow is implemented by allowing any component in a shape to be `None`. And the shape inference method of every operator will do its best job given an input shape which might have `None` in any dimension.
In this way partial shape inference will just become a feature inside the usual shape inference API, but not another kind of shape inference.

Hi,
I checked in /share/sw/modules/Core/cuda/7.5/ and apparently I have the wrong directory as it does not have an include folder.
CUDA on my system is actually installed to "/share/sw/free/cuda/7.5".
I added that folder to my config.mk to be the following;

```
#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#  Template configuration for compiling mxnet
#
#  If you want to change the configuration, please use the following
#  steps. Assume you are on the root directory of mxnet. First copy the this
#  file so that any local changes will be ignored by git
#
#  $ cp make/config.mk .
#
#  Next modify the according entries, and then compile by
#
#  $ make
#
#  or build in parallel with 8 threads
#
#  $ make -j8
#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

#---------------------
# choice of compiler
#--------------------

export CC = gcc
export CXX = g++
export NVCC = nvcc

# whether compile with debug
DEBUG = 1

# the additional link flags you want to add
ADD_LDFLAGS = -L/share/sw/free/cuda/7.5

# the additional compile flags you want to add
ADD_CFLAGS =

#---------------------------------------------
# matrix computation libraries for CPU/GPU
#---------------------------------------------

# whether use CUDA during compile
USE_CUDA = 1

# add the path to CUDA library to link and compile flag
# if you have already add them to environment variable, leave it as NONE
# USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda
USE_CUDA_PATH = /share/sw/free/cuda/7.5

# whether use CUDNN R3 library
USE_CUDNN = 1

# whether use cuda runtime compiling for writing kernels in native language (i.e. Python)
USE_NVRTC = 0

# whether use opencv during compilation
# you can disable it, however, you will not able to use
# imbin iterator
USE_OPENCV = 1

# use openmp for parallelization
USE_OPENMP = 0

# choose the version of blas you want to use
# can be: mkl, blas, atlas, openblas
USE_BLAS = openblas

# add path to intel library, you may need it for MKL, if you did not add the path
# to environment variable
USE_INTEL_PATH = NONE

#----------------------------
# distributed computing
#----------------------------

# whether or not to enable multi-machine supporting
USE_DIST_KVSTORE = 0

# whether or not allow to read and write HDFS directly. If yes, then hadoop is
# required
USE_HDFS = 0

# path to libjvm.so. required if USE_HDFS=1
LIBJVM=$(JAVA_HOME)/jre/lib/amd64/server

# whether or not allow to read and write AWS S3 directly. If yes, then
# libcurl4-openssl-dev is required, it can be installed on Ubuntu by
# sudo apt-get install -y libcurl4-openssl-dev
USE_S3 = 0

#----------------------------
# additional operators
#----------------------------

# path to folders containing projects specific operators that you don't want to put in src/operators
EXTRA_OPERATORS =


#----------------------------
# plugins
#----------------------------

# whether to use torch integration. This requires installing torch.
# TORCH_PATH = $(HOME)/torch
# MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/torch/torch.mk
```

I also modified my LD_LIBRARY_PATH, PATH, and LIBRARY_PATH:

```
export CUDA_HOME=/share/sw/free/cuda/7.5
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:${CUDA_HOME}/lib64
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:${CUDA_HOME}/lib
export LIBRARY_PATH=$LIBRARY_PATH:${CUDA_HOME}/lib64
export LIBRARY_PATH=$LIBRARY_PATH:${CUDA_HOME}/lib
export PATH=$PATH:/share/sw/free/cuda/7.5/
```

This feature is suppose to help doing shape inference for recurrent networks. Suppose a fully connected later is taking input from a recurrent state (a loop with time delay). Then shape inference will be complete impossible for this operator until we do a partial inference to get what is the shape for the recurrent state.
That's fine. It would be even better to note the type of elements in the array.

OK I looked over the unit test and looks like I misunderstood "partial shape inference". 
It looks like in your case it means "infer shape of the output when the shape of certain input is not fully determined". This is necessary for RNN in mxnet, I think essentially because mxnet doesn't allow declaration of a variable with shape.
While I was thinking about "infer shape of the output when only certain dimension of the shape can be inferred", e.g. select the first k rows of a matrix of known shape, with k being something computed in run time.

When linker cannot find a lib, find that lib and add its path to linker
path.

Hi,
Thanks for the reply.
How would I go about doing this? Adding paths to the LDFLAGS environment variable, LD_LIBRARY_PATH and LIBRARY_PATH didn't seem to help before.

according my understanding, the index is consistent with symbol's staticgraph dfs visit order. Reference https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/4616e8b0a3e8f9258d2403f533166718f82903bc/src/symbol/symbol.cc#L203-L215  

you can check with symbol.list_arguments. and set lr_scale with the index in the returned list

I forgot configure the USE_BLAS choice yesterday and I have corrected all the relative choices to make sure the project build with openblas, but the problem still exist.

the problem have been solvedthank you.
@winstywang All ready
Can this be accomplished by exposing num visible outputs?
@piiswrong nope. The number of outputs for slice_channel is not fixed. It depends on the parameters.

a) Do it with custom data iter as preprocessing.
b) do symetrical padding and crop your output with sym.Crop to throw away the extra outputs.

Is the return type of Slice still an array if there is only one output?
BTW, why do you need the return type before creating a symbol?

Thanks, option a wouldn't work because I would like to do that on symbols inside the network.
Wrt to option b, I would like to do this before a convolution (e.g. add 1px and then perform a convolution) and I don't think that there is a standalone function in mxnet for padding. Is there a way to pad on a symbol without modifying it?

I encountered the same issue, CPU version of mxnet is 3 times slower than caffe both using MKL. Did you solve the problem? @wangzhangup

This post reports on the same issue:
https://www.kaggle.com/c/second-annual-data-science-bowl/forums/t/18079/end-to-end-deep-learning-tutorial-0-0392/105458#post105458

I ran into the same situation as well. Not sure yet if the earlier releases solve the problem.
I see no objection from other developer. @vchuravy Can you do a rebase so that we can merge? Thanks!
@wangzhangup @uestcbingo Curious about this issue, mind listing the caffe model configuration?

I see now that this is probably related to issue #404, but it may deserve it's own issue since this is really about a family of common aggregation operations on tensors. I'm also wondering whether one way of accomplishing lots of these kinds of operations without spending the time writing the basic ops would be to use the torch modules. This could at least be a temporary way to increase functionality, right?

I noticed that too. It seems that the ImageRecordIter function generates a MXDataIter object with particular properties like random data augmentation, etc. Not sure why but I couldn't find the function definition anywhere -- probably just not understanding something about how the underlying code base works.

We already support these functions with torch modules. See doc/python/tutorial/torch_howto for detail.
For our own version, the NDArray function interface already support this. Unfortunately no one have the time to write these functions right now.
It's generated at the end of io.py from C++ code.

Will definitely try the torch interface.
Regarding the ndarray interface, from what I can see, there is a sum function, but it collapses across all elements of the tensor, returning a scalar. That's definitely useful and can be used to build stats like global means, variances, etc., from a tensor without going back to numpy. Maybe I'm not seeing it, but I can't find any way in the ndarray function interface to do sums across particular tensor dimensions. E.g. how do I compute the row sum of a matrix using ndarray?
I understand the lack of time issue and I'm happy to work towards contributing what I can but I want to make sure I don't duplicate efforts.

Ok, I see how I can compute row or column sums using dot products of a matrix with a row or column vector of 1s. I think that would allow me to do these basic aggregations in ndarray without using the torch interface or writing a specific op.
One thing I'm still unclear about since I'm new to mxnet is how to mix symbolic and ndarray operations. If I want to include ndarray operations in the symbolic graph, do I need to encapsulate them in a custom op?
Ah. That explains it. Useful to know if anyone wants to generate variants similar to ImageRecordIter.
Thanks a lot. It's a nice trick. :)

Many thanks for your help. I managed to do it with Torch's nn.Padding function :). 
The Torch bindings are really helpful!

What I'd like to do is just to save .params for every 5 or 10 epochs.
I tried to use mx.callback.do_checkpoint, but it couldn't specify such epoch intervals.

@hjk41 Not that I'm aware of. I have been thinking about adding profiling to the engine for a while. For example add a string tag to each Push and count time for each tag. But @tqchen Thinks this has negative performance implications.

BTW, there is a pretty easy fix for not fully using CPU: change mshadow/mshadow/tensor_cpu-inl.h:143 to a OpenMP parallel for. We have been talking about this for a while but no body has done it yet.
Use do_checkpoint. save_checkpoint is for internal use.

ok. Back in Minerva v2, we had some kind of lightweight profiling which can
be turned on when needed. I think we can do the same for mxnet.

For the mshadow fix, why isn't this enabled by default?

Just tried the mshadow trick. It does boosts the CPU utilization to 100%,
but lowers the overall speed.  I guess enabling OpenMP in that loop
causes a lot of cache coherence overhead.

Was due to cuda driver shutting down and some functions are called after the driver shutting down. Most of this exceptions are caught and ignored during destruction time. I guess there are some exceptions. 

Normally you can get over it by get some result from the model and run predictions. This is not the problem of scala package, but would be great if you can find where the error is thrown.

For example, it is caught here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/engine/threaded_engine.h#L290

If you can use gdb to find where the error was thrown, we can try add things to these places as well
Subclass DataIter and write your own data iterator

should the lr be so small? we often use lr=0.05. also we found
1. python's image resize function could affect the accuracy
2. use cudnn v4 instead of v3, the latter has bug on the pooling layer 

i think @antinucleon knows more about the issues.

which returns a matrix full of zeros instead of ones. By the way, the same erroneous behavior occurs with the windows version of python package build. Again, release 20151228 does not have this behavior.
